headline: Roasted Turkey Legs
description: This simple recipe for roasted turkey legs infuses the drumsticks with lots of flavor thanks to a compound butter. Chicken broth keeps the meat moist.

video.description: Roasted turkey legs are a great choice for Thanksgiving for smaller families. But this tender and moist meat is delicious any time of year. In this video learn this simple recipe that's also very adaptable to variations. Experiment with seasonings, add some minced garlic or onion, or change the herbs. If you like dark meat, this is a great recipe.
video.name: How to Make Roasted Turkey Legs

name: Roasted Turkey Legs
recipeIngredient: 4 to 6 turkey legs or drumsticks (bone-in, skin-on)

recipeInstructions.text: Gather the ingredients. Preheat the oven to 350 F.
Pat the turkey legs dry with paper towels and place them in a large roasting pan. Avoid rinsing poultry in the sink; that will just spread bacteria around your kitchen.
Create a compound butter by mixing the softened butter, salt, pepper, poultry seasoning, and thyme in a small bowl.
Rub this mixture over the turkey legs. You can also rub it on the flesh under the skin for even more flavor.
Pour the chicken broth into the pan around the turkey legs. This will help keep the legs moist.

Roast the turkey legs for 1 hour and 30 minutes to 1 hour and 40 minutes or until a meat thermometer registers 170 F. Remove the roasting pan from the oven, cover it with foil, and let stand for 10 minutes.
You can serve whole legs or slice the meat off the bones and serve it that way.

review.reviewBody: I made the garlic butter to spread on the turkey legs. Couple questions, the instructions and photographs don't say to place them on a rack in a roasting pan, but the video shows them sitting on a rack. I do not have mine on a rack, they are sitting in the pan with the broth surrounding them. Is this okay? Also should I turn them halfway through roasting?
I have made this recipe twice and my family loves it. I added 1 tsp of garlic powder the second time.

I've been doing this for years. I found the best flavour & a way to keep them moist is to peel back the skin from the large end down to the knuckle, slicing the membrane that holds on the skin as needed to get it off in one piece. Then pat dry the meat, rub the butter or seasonings all over the meat, then pull the skin back on, butter the outsides & roast, with no rack in 1/4 inch of water, not stock, flavourful but not necessary. Mine are always cooked to an internal temp of 165'f in less than an hour, turning once. I usually cook 2 trays, at a time, flash freeze them, then into a big bag, suck all the air out, freeze for a couple months & use for individual plates or sandwiches etc. Then use the pan drippings to make a gravy that I put into ice cube trays, freeze then into a bag for individual servings/plates. I usually get about a quart of excellent gravy out of 12 legs. A local store in town has a $1.49 day where they are sold for $1.49 a pound. (Pre covid). Most times I just use a dry rub of mixed seasonings I put into a shaker. I found a great turkey rub mix at Alton Browns site years ago. There are a lot of spices in it, but I limit the salt, but definitely garlic powder. Now I crave turkey drums & beer!
This recipe is perfect! I used it today and the turkey drumsticks came out so moist and delicious!! Saving it!!

i am trying this right now - scored 4 huge turkey legs at the butchers yesterday and am doing lemony rosemary with garlic on 2 and cranberry orange and brown sugar on the other 2 - they have just gone into the oven and when cooked will freeze them down for my husband and i when i cant be bothered cooking much - will just roast a few veges to go with them at the time - will even try making gravy with the pan drippings and freeze that to use later - fingers crossed because i have only cooked turkey once before about 40 years ago and i didnt enjoy it then - hope this is a better way - thanks for making me try something new
